poem:
Title: "A Pub Discussion on Comedy"

At a round table lathered in pint shadows,
A confession slipped from my youthful mouth,
Praising Blackadder and Morecambe's butterfly wit,
A kinship cast with the seasoned British souls,
In televisual laughter, age bears no weight,
Just shared mirth under the evening's comic gaze.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "I am not an elderly white man. But you’d think so from my taste in TV comedy | Charlie Brinkhurst-Cuff I have just realised I have the same taste in TV comedy as an elderly British white man. Sitting around a table full of pints after a recent football match (we lost), the conversation turned to our favourite comedy shows. There I was, extolling the humour of Blackadder II and the joys of a Morecambe". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: I am not an elderly white man. But you’d think so from my taste in TV comedy | Charlie Brinkhurst-Cuff I have just realised I have the same taste in TV comedy as an elderly British white man. Sitting around a table full of pints after a recent football match (we lost), the conversation turned to our favourite comedy shows. There I was, extolling the humour of Blackadder II and the joys of a Morecambe
